This is still my favorite book, I think I've read it three times now. I brought it to the hospital to read while I was recovering from brain surgery.

So what if it's an unrealistic fairy tale? It's meant to be read that way.

Title: Collected Fictions
Author: Jorge Luis Borges
My Review:
Edit: I’m dumb. Haven’t actually finished this yet. These stories are a lot richer and more creative than I expected.
The stories weren't bad, they did contain a lot of references that felt outdated and difficult for me to grasp. I can see how influential this writing was in inspiring great modern sci-fi though. The best stories were Tlon & Babel.

To be honest, I was hoping for a lot more, sharper focused alternate universe stories like Library of Babel, and less general musings about nature.

Title: Brave New World
Author: Aldous Huxley
My Review:
Thoughts
-- tech is not necessarily suppression of human emotion
-- its telling a blip of history far past the end of it
-- Brave New World is a story and not a philosophical manifesto : while the issues of human suffering and meaning are present it is not necessarily satirical and no strong beliefs are forced on the reader
-- it is a very "political" book
--The dichotomy drawn between god/various conceptions of suffering and various conceptions of "happiness" is fuzzy and not super justified -- this makes the book itself somewhat topical. I don't think eliminating cancer and syphilis is at all debatable so that was a weird concept to lump into the rest.

Title: The Book of Disquiet: The Complete Edition
Author: Fernando Pessoa

Title: Little Eyes
Author: Samanta Schweblin
My Review: Gave it a few chapters before realizing that it was really not about to get better. The one scene with any emotional heft was the senior living center and that was really short and did not capitalize. Black mirror, but boring and mundane.

Title: Parable of the Sower (Earthseed, #1)

My Review: Visionary and chilling image of an America that might as well be ours soon.

Title: What I Talk About When I Talk About Running
Author: Haruki Murakami
My Review: Worth reading for sure, but did not make much as much of an impact on me as I had expected. In a way, Murakami chooses to keep a certain ambiguity around running & its meaning to him, which was kind of disappointing.

Title: Severance
Author: Ling  Ma
My Review:
This was going to be a two-star review until the last third of the book, where things got significantly better.

Some parts don't make sense: why is Bob fevered only at nighttime? What is the purpose of the "facility" anyways? And while the whole US vs China manufacturing/immigrant story is nice, its not the same nostalgia as New York.

What I liked: The immigrant story hidden inside is poignant at times, but what I really liked was the construction of Shen Fever as repetitive motions -- the idea of common routines, of collective memory of malls and living spaces. The connection between stalking and consumerism was also really interesting, but it could have explored more thoroughly along with the connections between urban life/nostalgia-- maybe there were two novels here.

Title: Artemis
Author: Andy Weir
My Review: Passably good speculative fiction with some not-entirely-unexpected twists.

Title: Ethics: A Very Short Introduction

My Review: I thought this answered important concerns and left appropriately important questions unresolved/up to the reader. I also didn't think the author was particularly biased.

Title: Invisible Cities
Author: Italo Calvino
My Review:
This book was very evocative, crazily inventive at times, and has some very well thought out symmetry. That being said, several of the cities are really kind of boring: I can see what is supposed to be interesting about them, but it doesn't quite work out-- maybe lost in translation.

At any rate, the book as a whole is able to blend modern and ancient references extremely well -- there's a deep inquiry about WHAT a concept, a graveyard, a port city really is, irrespective of the temporal aspects of it. The Mongol Khanate is eternal!

Title: Collection of Sand
Author: Italo Calvino
My Review: I really, really wanted to like this book after reading Invisible Cities but the subject matter and the diluted quality of the commentary is very difficult to get through. There are interesting parts like the Traveler in the Map -- I think that if this was written around contemporary artifacts it would be more relevant.

It's "nice".

Possibly the most influential book on my thinking over the grades 7-11th and why I find similar ideas are so interesting -- because they are hidden patterns and people aren't catching them.
